DataElement.preferredName: Follow-Up Embodiment/Outcomes Questionnaire Feelings About Arm or Leg Most of the Time Status 4 Point Scale
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Persons' stated observation of their feelings most of the time about their arm or leg, using a 4 point scale.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Follow-Up Embodiment/Outcomes Questionnaire Feelings About Arm or Leg Most of the Time Status
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A set of questions and responses designed to evaluate an individual's self-reported feeling about their limbs._A question about an individual's feelings about their arm or leg most of the time._A response indicating that something happens or happened most of the time._A condition or state at a particular time.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A set of questions and responses designed to evaluate an individual's self-reported feeling about their limbs.

Concepts.definition: A set of questions and responses designed to evaluate an individual's self-reported feeling about their limbs.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Process and results associated with self-reported measures and instruments, surveys, other tools

DataElementConcept.origin: DCI CRF:  Duke Cancer Institute Case Report Form

ValueDomain.preferredName: Follow-Up Embodiment/Outcomes Questionnaire Feelings 4 Point Scale
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A four point ordered reference set that describes the patient's closest feelings most of the time about their arm or leg.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A response indicating: I never realized I could do so many things with my arm/leg; I'm used to my arm/leg now, it's part of me; it's amazing what you can learn to do.

Concepts.definition: A response indicating: I never realized I could do so many things with my arm/leg; I'm used to my arm/leg now, it's part of me; it's amazing what you can learn to do.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A response indicating: I've got to accept my arm/leg the way it is; I'm learning how to use my arm/leg more and just trying to not really concentrate on it, but try to adapt my arm/leg to different ways of life; I'm going to have to learn to live with arm/leg the way it is now.

Concepts.definition: A response indicating: I've got to accept my arm/leg the way it is; I'm learning how to use my arm/leg more and just trying to not really concentrate on it, but try to adapt my arm/leg to different ways of life; I'm going to have to learn to live with arm/leg the way it is now.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A response indicating: I'm very aware of my arm/leg; my arm/leg feels like an alien part; my arm/leg has a mind of its own; I hide or cover my arm/leg; it seems that my arm/leg is not part of me.

Concepts.definition: A response indicating: I'm very aware of my arm/leg; my arm/leg feels like an alien part; my arm/leg has a mind of its own; I hide or cover my arm/leg; it seems that my arm/leg is not part of me.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A response indicating: I don't even know my arm/leg is there; my arm/leg is back to normal as far as I am concerned; I rarely or never think about my arm/leg.

Concepts.definition: A response indicating: I don't even know my arm/leg is there; my arm/leg is back to normal as far as I am concerned; I rarely or never think about my arm/leg.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Process and results associated with self-reported measures and instruments, surveys, other tools

Concepts.definition: An ordered reference standard used to measure incremental changes.

ValueDomain.origin: DCI CRF:  Duke Cancer Institute Case Report Form

ReferenceDocuments.name: Below are a number of stateme
ReferenceDocuments.description: Below are a number of statements that are divided into four groups.  First, read through all of the statements.  Then put a check mark beside the ONE group of statements that is closest to how you feel about your arm or leg MOST OF THE TIME.

DataElement.origin: DCI CRF:  Duke Cancer Institute Case Report Form
